variance_contributors.root_cause: Significantly higher actual costs driven by 4 major component failures (Gearbox, Generator, Blade, Transformer). Likely due to components reaching wear limits (5 years age) and potentially insufficient predictive/preventive maintenance in prior periods.
Increased need for specialized external labor and equipment (e.g., cranes) to handle the higher-than-budgeted number of major unscheduled repairs and component replacements during the year.
Higher consumption of spare parts to address the increased unscheduled repairs. May also indicate reactive purchasing or inadequate initial stock levels for components that failed.

key_budget_priorities: Improve Reliability: Execute planned major maintenance (bearings, generator) and 5-year inspections (gearbox, blades) to proactively address component aging and reduce failures.

Control Unscheduled Costs: Reduce reliance on reactive maintenance by investing heavily in scheduled and predictive activities, aiming to lower the high unscheduled repair costs experienced last year.
Enhance Asset Performance: Implement the control system upgrade across all turbines to potentially improve energy production, efficiency, and long-term operational health.
cost_saving_measures: Proactive Component Replacement/Overhaul: Addressing known risks (WT-05, WT-12 bearings/generator) prevents more costly failures and extended downtime.

Fleet-wide Inspections & Upgrades: Performing 5-year gearbox/blade inspections and control system upgrades aims to identify issues early and improve overall operational efficiency, reducing long-term costs.
Optimized Spare Parts Management: Budgeting for recommended spare parts additions ensures parts availability, minimizing downtime and potentially avoiding premium costs for urgent orders.
